candidates.title: Were Will and Jaden Smith Killed in a Car Crash?
candidates.content:
Claim:
Actor Will Smith and his son Jaden Smith were killed in a car crash in December 2019.
Rating:
False
About this rating
In December 2019, social media users began encountering a post proclaiming that actor Will Smith and his son, rapper Jaden Smith, had "died in a crash after a "car and truck collision":
This post was a hoax, as neither Will nor Jaden Smith had died or been seriously injured in an automobile accident. Clicking through on the social media post led users to a rogue website which displayed a fake CNN video announcing the supposed "shocking" death of the Smiths (along with some other adult content):
The purpose of this hoax appeared to be to bait users into clicking to view the video as a means of driving them to malicious web pages, and to trick them into sharing the hoax post on social media in order to spread it further. Users are strongly advised not to visit to the website that underlies this hoax post and not to click on anything displayed there.
candidates.description: Fake death notices are often spread for malicious purposes.

result.explanation: The news caption claiming that actor Will Smith and his son Jaden Smith died in a car crash is clearly contradicted by the retrieved related articles. The primary source, a fact-checking article from Snopes, explicitly states that the claim about their deaths was a hoax circulating in December 2019. According to this source, the social media posts alleging that both Smiths had died in a car and truck collision were false and were intended as a malicious attempt to trick users into clicking on links that led to rogue websites. The article's analysis lays out that neither Will nor Jaden Smith had died or suffered serious injuries from such an accident, thus debunking the caption entirely. Additionally, it highlights the nature and purpose of the hoax, indicating an organized effort to misinform the public and draw traffic to dubious sites. The fact that this claim has been specifically identified as false by Snopes—a reputable fact-checking organization—reinforces the inaccuracy of the original news caption. Given all of this, there is a strong basis for asserting that the caption is not only unsupported but is indeed false, resulting in a low confidence score since there is significant evidence against the narrative it presents.
